intro: Haplopappus megacephalus, commonly known as the big-headed pappus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive bracts. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and produces small, yellowish to brownish flowers. Its most notable feature is the enlarged, spherical pappus that aids in wind dispersal of its seeds. The botanical structure of Haplopappus megacephalus reflects its adaptation to arid environments, with reduced leaves and a compact growth form.
